required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: SGM-101 in Locally Advanced and Recurrent Rectal Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Multicenter, Open-label, Controlled, Parallel Arms Clinical Study on the Performance of SGM-101, a Fluorochrome-labeled Anti-carcino-embryonic Antigen (CEA) Monoclonal Antibody, for Locally Advanced or Recurrent Rectal Cancer Patients Undergoing Curative Surgery

collaborator.agency: Centre for Human Drug Research, Netherlands

brief_summary.textblock: Near-infrared fluorescence-guided oncologic surgery (EGOS) with the use of a tumor specific tracer (SGM-101) developed by Surgimab can provide valuable intra-operative information about tumor location and extensiveness, which can be difficult to detect with conventional visual and tactile feedback. Hence, this information could aid in intra-operative decision making and therewith foster complete resection margins and less extensive surgery. Subsequently, this may drastically improve patient care by improving oncologic outcome.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Prospectively inclusion treatment arm. Compared to historical cohort.

arm_group.description: Patients included with locally advanced rectal cancer SGM-101 10mg, 3-5 days prior to surgery
Patients included with (locally) recurrent rectal cancer SGM-101 10mg, 3-5 days prior to surgery
